revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2017}}
{{Infobox building | building_name = B&O Railroad Headquarters Building - Hotel Monaco | image = B&O Headquarters Building, Baltimore.jpg | caption = B&O Headquarters Building, now a Hotel Monaco<ref>{{cite web|title=Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Company Headquarters Building, 2 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD|url=https://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/hh/item/md1569/|publisher=Historic American Buildings Survey/Historic American Engineering Record/Historic American Landscapes Survey}}</ref> | name = Hotel Monaco | location = 2 North Charles St., [[Baltimore, Maryland]] | map_type = Baltimore | coordinates = {{coord|39|17|23|N|76|36|58|W|display=inline,title}} | completion_date = 1906 | building_type = Mixed-use: Office, Hotel and Restaurant | architectural_style = [[Beaux-Arts architecture]] | floor_count = 13 | floor_area = <!-- {{convert||sqft|abbr=on}} --> | architect = [[J. Harleston Parker|Parker & Thomas]] assisted by Herbert D. Hale and [[Henry G. Morse]] }}
[[File:B&O Railroad Headquarters Building, Baltimore, MD 1906.JPG|thumb|Mercury, the Roman god of commerce, (left) and an allegorical feature called Progress of Industry, (right) cradling a locomotive, adorn the front entrance of the current Hotel Monaco at 2 North Charles Street.]]
[[File:B&O Headquarters Building, circa 1910.JPG|thumb|B&O Headquarters Building, circa 1910, soon after completion of construction. Note the trolley tracks on North Charles and West Baltimore Streets.]]
[[File:B&O Headquarters Building Plaque in Baltimore, MD.JPG|thumb|Oscar G. Murray was the president of the B&O Railroad, when their new Headquarters Building opened in 1906. His 1914 will established a fund for his employees’ widows and orphans. It survives a 100 years later and is administered today by the Baltimore Community Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oscar G. Murrary - An Evolving Legacy|url=http://www.bcf.org/bLearnbBCFandouractionagenda/AboutBCF/Stories/ViewStory/tabid/399/ArticleId/283/An-Evolving-Legacy.aspx}}</ref>]]
The '''B&O Railroad Headquarters Building''' is a historic [[office building]] at [[Charles Street (Baltimore)|2 North Charles Street]] in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]. It is a 13-story, 220 foot [[skyscraper]] designed by the Boston and Baltimore-based architectural firm of [[J. Harleston Parker|Parker & Thomas]], and constructed in 1904-1906.
==Architectural History==
"When the original [[Second Empire architecture|Second Empire style]] headquarters on the corner of Baltimore and Calvert street was destroyed in the [[Great Baltimore Fire]] of 1904, [[Baltimore & Ohio Railroad]] executives decided to build a new 13 story steel-framed building two blocks west of the old site. The building's entrance is adorned by two sculptures: Mercury, the Roman god for commerce, and a figure named Progress of Industry, which holds a torch and a locomotive; Progress of Industry clearly invokes the company's position not only as an industry leader, but also the company's aspiration to be a vehicle of progress."<ref>{{cite web|title=Baltimore Architecture: B&O Railroad Headquarters Building|url=http://csit121.com/san181084/Project/buildings/BORailHQ.html#sthash.1ZQZsUev.ZI4NLR1P.dpbs}}</ref>
It was designed by the architectural firm of [[J. Harleston Parker|Parker and Thomas]] of Baltimore and Boston, assisted by Herbert D. Hale and [[Henry G. Morse]], and built by the construction firm of the brothers W. W. and E. A. Wells of Chicago. The same group had successfully teamed up a couple of years earlier on the [[Belvedere Hotel]], an eleven-story [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] building, about one mile up North Charles Street in the [[Mount Vernon, Baltimore|Mount Vernon]] area of downtown Baltimore.
"The 13-story office building, built in 1906, served as headquarters for the [[Baltimore & Ohio Railroad]] for 75 years. The building's beauty and elegance of its marbled lobbies, ornate stairs and [[Louis Comfort Tiffany|Tiffany]] stained-glass windows became an instant landmark in downtown Baltimore and it symbolized the power and prestige of America's largest and oldest railroad."<ref>{{cite web|title=B&O Building Historic Restoration and Renovation|url=http://www.rcgarchitects.com/rcg-projects/commercial/B-and-O-building-historic-restoration-and-renovation/}}</ref> The impressive building includes seven different kinds of marble imported from six countries representing four continents.<ref>{{cite web|title=.BlueStone Real Estate Capital Secures $48M Acquisition and Construction Loan for Iconic B&O Building|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BlueStone+Real+Estate+Capital+Secures+$48M+Acquisition+and...-a0168060611}}</ref> The first 3 floors of the exterior façade are clad in New Hampshire granite, while Bedford stone is utilized from the fourth floor and above. The trim is terra cotta tile. The building's H shape design provides for a large number of window offices. The ornate main lobby contains two white marble staircases, grand chandeliers and many decorative details.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kenwood Management Web Site|url=http://www.kenwoodmgt.com/property_bo_building.html}}</ref>
As the building neared completion in 1906, The Baltimore Sun ran a glowing piece under the headline, ''A Palace for B. and O. - Headquarters a Monument to City's Progressiveness'', "A model of architecture, with ornamentation and decorations, inside and out, of the richest and most up-to-date design, the new Baltimore and Ohio building, now nearing completion at the northwest corner of Baltimore and Charles Streets, opposite the new home of the Baltimore Sun, will be a lasting monument to Baltimore's progressiveness. Not only is it the largest office building in Maryland, and perhaps along the Atlantic Coast south of Philadelphia, but it ranks among the finest in the world in style and completeness."<ref>{{cite news|title=A PALAGE FOR B. AND O.: Headquarters A Monument To City's Progressiveness|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|date=June 24, 1906|page=7}}</ref> The article went on to relate the tremendous skill of the craftsmen, the gigantic size of the structure, including 1,600 windows, and the great number of employees, who would work there, 1,000 in all, 500 of whom could be fed at any one time in the company dining room.
When the B&O Headquarters Building was completed, it was the second tallest structure in Baltimore to the 16 story 249 foot [[One Calvert Plaza|Continental Trust Company Building]], two blocks away at 201 East Baltimore St., which was constructed in 1900-1901 to designs prepared by the Chicago skyscraper architect [[Daniel Burnham|D.H. Burnham and Company]].<ref>[[List of tallest buildings in Baltimore]]</ref>
The current occupant of the building, The Hotel Monaco, rhapsodizes on its website, "The (B&O) Headquarters opened its doors at midnight on September 12, 1906 to the dazzling spectacle of more than 5,000 electric lights that 'burst into fire and presented a grand spectacle', as reported by The (Baltimore) Sun. The newspaper went on to point out that Oscar G. Murray, B&O Railroad president, chose to move into his office suite the next day, September 13. 'The structure is 13 stories high; Murray started in the railroad business on January 13, 1872; and he was elected the thirteenth president of the railroad,' furthered the news report. Of course, Murray's office number was 13 and his phone extension was the same. Amusing anecdotes aside, the building is known for architectural greatness. The exterior is dignified and monumental, with beautiful carving and ornamental work showing off the craftsmanship of yesteryear. Perhaps one of the most compelling features is the building's statuary over the main entrance. Believed to predate the statuary at New York's [[Grand Central Terminal|Grand Central Station]] and designed by John Evans & Co. of Boston,<ref>{{cite web|title=Boston Public Library - John Evans & Co. Collection |url=http://www.bpl.org/research/special/collections.htm#e |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705115712/http://www.bpl.org/research/special/collections.htm |archivedate=2013-07-05 }}</ref> the figure of Mercury and an allegorical feature cradling a locomotive represent transportation and commerce."<ref>{{cite web|title=A Historical Look at Inner Harbor Hotels: The Monaco Baltimore -|url=http://www.monaco-baltimore.com/hotel/history.html}}</ref>
The B&O Railroad Headquarters Building lies within the Baltimore [[Business and Government Historic District]], which was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1987.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Register of Historic Places|url=http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natreg/docs/All_Data.html}}</ref> In 2001 the City of Baltimore's Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation<ref>{{cite web|title=City of Baltimore Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation|url=http://www.baltimorecity.gov/Government/BoardsandCommissions/HistoricalArchitecturalPreservation.aspx}}</ref> and the [[Maryland Historical Trust]] designated the B&O Building one the city's ten most historically consequential buildings.<ref>{{cite web|title=BlueStone Real Estate Capital Secures $48M Acquisition and Construction Loan for Iconic B&O Building in Baltimore|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BlueStone+Real+Estate+Capital+Secures+$48M+Acquisition+and...-a0168060611}}</ref>
==Recent real estate history==
The owner of the property, Baltimore and Charles Associates, went bankrupt in 2010 and the property was then subdivided into a "condominium regime" and Kimpton bought the hotel space and restaurant space for approximately $33 million and Kenwood Management Co. of Bethesda,<ref>{{cite web|title=Kenwood Management Company|url=http://www.kenwoodmgt.com/index.html}}</ref> purchased the office space for $1.3 million. Baltimore and Charles Associates, spent about $65 million to buy and renovate the B&O Building from 2007 to 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kimpton buying part of B&O Building|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2011-03-07/business/bs-bz-hotel-monaco-20110307_1_hotel-monaco-baltimore-b-o-building-baltimore-and-charles-associates}}</ref> Philadelphia-based Arc Wheeler LLC, was the project's lead developer and at the time was also planning to redevelop the former McCormick & Co. spice plant site at Conway and Light streets downtown, which fell through.<ref>{{cite web|title=Baltimore’s B&O Building could hit the auction block|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/baltimore/print-edition/2010/11/05/baltimores-bo-building-could-hit-the.html}}</ref>
The original $48 million acquisition and construction loan for the B&O Building was arranged by Philadelphia-based, BlueStone Real Estate Capital, a real estate investment bank.<ref>{{cite web|title=BlueStone Real Estate Capital Secures $48M Acquisition and Construction Loan for Iconic B&O Building in Baltimore|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BlueStone+Real+Estate+Capital+Secures+$48M+Acquisition+and...-a0168060611}}</ref>
The architect for the historic restoration and renovation project was RCG from Baltimore.<ref>{{cite web|title=RCG Architects|url=http://www.rcgarchitects.com/rcg-projects/commercial/B-and-O-building-historic-restoration-and-renovation/}}</ref> The restoration received an Award of Excellence by the Maryland Society of American Institute of Architects<ref>{{cite web|title=Maryland Society AIA|url=http://www.aiamd.org/}}</ref> and numerous other awards for historic preservation.
==Current use==
Since 2009, following a 3-year renovation, the B&O Headquarters Building has been a 202-room Hotel Monaco,<ref>{{cite web|title=Hotel Monaco Baltimore|url=http://www.monaco-baltimore.com/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Owens|first=Donna M.|title=Get a room: 5 hotels worth a visit with your Valentine|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/travel/bal-baltimore-hotels-valentines-day-pictures-20140124,0,1195.photogallery|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|date=January 26, 2014}}</ref> a [[Kimpton Hotels & Restaurants|Kimpton property]], the largest boutique hotel chain in the U.S., and has housed the B&O American Brasserie.<ref>{{cite web|title=B&O American Brasserie|url=http://www.bandorestaurant.com/}}</ref> It also has three floors of office space and BB&T on the first floor. As configured currently it has 220,500 square feet of space.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat-inline|B&O Railroad Headquarters Building}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:BandO Railroad Headquarters Building}} [[Category:Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]] [[Category:Beaux-Arts architecture in Maryland]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Baltimore]] [[Category:Downtown Baltimore]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1906]] [[Category:Commercial buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Maryland]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Baltimore]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Baltimore]] [[Category:Skyscraper hotels in Baltimore]]

page.title: British International School of New York

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Iloveballlons263|Iloveballlons263]] ([[User talk:Iloveballlons263|talk]]) to last version by Nylon2000
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox school | name = British International School of New York | image = Watersideplaza crop.JPG | alt = | caption = [[Waterside Plaza]]; the British International School of New York is located at the base of the second tower from the left | location = 20 Waterside Plaza, New York, New York 10010 USA | country = United States of America | coordinates = {{coord|40|44|12.3|N|73|58|22|W |display=title}} | pushpin_map = United States Manhattan#USA New York City#USA New York#USA | established = 2006 | opened = 2006 | website ={{url|http://www.bis-ny.org/}} }} The '''British International School of New York (BIS-NY)''' was established in 2006 at [[Waterside Plaza]], an upscale development on the [[East River]] in the [[Kips Bay]] neighborhood of [[Manhattan]], New York City.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hogwarts on the Hudson |first=Geoffrey |last=Gray |url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/16060/ |magazine=New York |date=19 February 2006 |accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref> The student body is a mix of British [[expatriate]]s, American nationals and students from a mix of other countries, and includes both boys and girls. The school serves students from age three up to fourteen years old. Its facilities include a swimming pool, secured playground, gymnasium, and [[Smart Board]]s in every classroom. The school offers rolling admissions, so that children can enter the school throughout the year, as long as there is space available. This is particularly helpful for families who have been transferred internationally at short notice.
The school teaches a mix of the [[National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)|English National Curriculum]] blended with the methodology of the [[International Baccalaureate]]. French and Spanish are taught at every level of the school, with other languages available as after-school options. Individual music lessons are also offered in addition to the class lessons, and a summer camp is run through the months of June to August.
The school's enrollment has increased regularly, which has led to the school's continued expansion. Recently, the school opened a new building adjacent to the cafeteria which contains an office and two classrooms specifically designed to meet the needs of the older students as they head into [[middle school]]. From September 2018 the school launches its Upper School offering the acclaimed Cambridge International IGCSE and A-Level programme to its students.
The British International School of New York is the sister school of [[Abercorn School]] in [[London, England|London]], England.
== Clubs and extracurricular activities == The school has a debate team that participates in the English-speaking Union Big Apple Debate league.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.esuus.org/esu/programs/middle_school_debate/NYDL/|title=New York Debate League - English-Speaking Union of the United States|website=www.esuus.org|access-date=2017-04-10}}</ref>
Most clubs run from 3:30pm-4:30pm on school days, though some clubs can run to 5:30 or 6:00. The clubs include Arabic, Ballet, Chess, Coding, Fencing, Global Chefs, Ice Skating, Karate, Mandarin, Robotics, Table Tennis and Yoga.
Some notable clubs of the school are Empire State of Sound (The school's show choir) and the school play. Which recent performances have included Peter Pan, Wizard of Oz, Bye Bye Birdie and Beauty and the Beast. With casts of up to 70 children from grades 3-8.
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{About|trade organizations globally|the American business lobbying organization|United States Chamber of Commerce}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} [[File:65 Liberty Street 9484.JPG|thumb|right|240px|Former headquarters of [[Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York]], the oldest Chamber of commerce in the [[United States]], established in 1768 during the British Colonial Period]] A '''chamber of commerce''' (or '''board of trade''') is a form of [[business network]], for example, a local organization of [[business]]es whose goal is to further the interests of businesses. [[Business owner]]s in towns and cities form these local societies to advocate on behalf of the [[business sector|business community]]. Local businesses are members, and they elect a board of directors or executive council to set policy for the chamber. The board or council then hires a President, CEO or Executive Director, plus staffing appropriate to size, to run the organization.
The first chamber of commerce was founded in 1599 in [[Marseille, France]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.cci.fr/web/organisation-du-reseau/histoire|title= 1599 Création à Marseille de la première Chambre de Commerce.|accessdate= 18 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://marseille.tv/tourisme/histoire-de-marseille/|title= Le port de Marseille, qui possède la plus ancienne Chambre de Commerce de France (fondée en 1599), acquiert une notoriété Mondiale|accessdate= 18 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marseilleinternationale.com/?q=1559 |title=Marseille, la Chambre, la plus vieille de France, crée en 1559 par Henri IV |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401025738/http://www.marseilleinternationale.com/?q=1559 |archivedate=1 April 2012 }}</ref><ref>[[André-Pierre Nouvion]], ''Origine et histoire des juridictions consulaires et des Chambres de Commerce et d'Industrie Françaises'', 2002</ref> Another official chamber of commerce would follow 65 years later, probably{{vague|date=April 2017}} in [[Bruges]], then part of the [[Spanish Netherlands]].
The world's oldest English-speaking chamber of commerce is the [[Jersey]] Chamber founded in February 1768,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerseychamber.com/about-us |title=About Chamber |publisher=Jersey Chamber of Commerce}}</ref> the same year the [[Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York|New York City Chamber]] was founded,<ref name="Bishop1918">{{cite book|author= Joseph Bucklin Bishop|title= A chronicle of one hundred & fifty years: the Chamber of commerce of the state of New York, 1768-1918|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=koZCAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1|accessdate= 8 February 2012|year= 1918|publisher= C. Scribner's sons|page= 5}}</ref> The oldest known existing chamber in the English-speaking world with continuous records, the [[Glasgow]] Chamber of Commerce,<ref>[http://www.glasgowchamberonline.org/page.asp?id=2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090605111039/http://www.glasgowchamberonline.org/page.asp?id=2|date=5 June 2009}}</ref> was founded in 1783. However, [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] Chamber of Commerce<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.hull-humber-chamber.co.uk/the-chamber/about-the-chamber.aspx |title= Hull Humber-chamber|publisher= hull-humber-chamber.co.uk |date= |accessdate= 28 November 2013}}</ref> is the UK's oldest, followed by those of [[Leeds]] and of [[Belfast]] in [[Northern Ireland|present day Northern Ireland]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
As a non-governmental institution, a chamber of commerce has no direct role in the writing and passage of laws and regulations that affect businesses. It may however, [[lobbying|lobby]] in an attempt to get laws passed that are favorable to businesses.
==Characteristics== Membership in an individual chamber can range from a few dozen to well over 800,000, as is the case with the [[Paris Île-de-France Regional Chamber of Commerce and Industry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cci-paris-idf.fr/cci-region/contenus/expertise-services-local-action-paris-ile-de-france-regional-commerce-and-industry-your-side|title=Expertise, services, local action: the Paris Île-de-France Regional Commerce and Industry is by your side|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> Some chamber organizations in China report even larger membership numbers. Chambers of commerce can range in scope from individual neighborhoods within a city or town up to an international chamber of commerce.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cipe.org/programs/ba/pdf/BA_VF_04-20-2007.pdf |title=Victor Fedotov, Organization and Legal Models of Chambers |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=21 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106134935/http://www.cipe.org/programs/ba/pdf/BA_VF_04-20-2007.pdf |archivedate=6 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In the United States, chambers do not operate in the same manner as the [[Better Business Bureau]] in that, while the BBB has the authority to bind its members under a formal operation doctrine (and, thus, can remove them if complaints arise regarding their services), the local chamber membership is either voluntary or required by law. In addition, Chambers represent the interests of businesses, while the BBB represents both the interests of businesses and the general public.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} Some Chambers are partially funded by local government, others are non-profit, and some are a combination of the two. Chambers of commerce also can include [[economic development]] corporations or groups (though the latter can sometimes be a formal branch of a local government, the groups work together and may in some cases share office facilities) as well as tourism and visitor bureaus.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
Some chambers have joined state, national (such as the United States Chamber of Commerce and the [[British Chambers of Commerce]]) and even international bodies (such as [[Eurochambres]], the [[International Chamber of Commerce]] (ICC), Worldchambers). Currently, there are about 13,000 chambers registered in the official Worldchambers Network registry, and the chamber of commerce network is the largest business network globally. This network is informal, with each local chamber incorporated and operating separately, rather than as a chapter of a national or state chamber. {{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
==Chamber models==
===Community, city and regional chambers=== Chambers of commerce in the United States can be considered community, city, regional, state, or nationwide ([[United States Chamber of Commerce]]). City Chambers work on the local level to bring the business community together to develop strong local networks, which can result in a business-to-business exchange. In most cases, city Chambers work with their local government, such as their mayor, their city council and local representatives to develop pro-business initiatives.<ref name="Weir2007_121"/> There are also bilateral chambers of commerce that link the business environments of two countries (e.g. [[Romanian-American Chamber of Commerce]], Moldovan–American Chamber of Commerce).
===Community chambers=== Community chambers of commerce started{{when?|date=October 2017}} in the UK and later spread to in the US, becoming city chambers of commerce as communities developed and became larger. Community chambers of commerce are smaller and most{{quantify|date=October 2017}} have a limit on numbers of members.<ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.todayschamber.com/community-chambers-of-commerce |title= Community Chambers of Commerce|publisher= |accessdate= 1 October 2014 }} </ref>
===City chambers=== [[File:Marlborough Regional Chamber Of Commerce Exterior.jpg|thumb|240px|left|alt=The Marlborough Regional Chamber of Commerce in Marlborough, Massachusetts|The Marlborough Regional Chamber of Commerce in [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]]]] City chambers of commerce have a long history in the US. The Charleston Chamber of Commerce is one of the oldest, dating back to colonial 1773.<ref>{{cite web|last1=United States Chamber of Commerce|title=U.S. Chamber of Commerce: The Early Years|url=https://www.uschamber.com/sites/default/files/uscc_HistoryBook.pdf|website=U.S. Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> That same year, Boston's Chamber of Commerce organized a seminal tax protest: [[Boston Tea Party|The Boston Tea Party]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=United State Chamber of Commerce|title=U.S. Chamber of Commerce: The Early Years|url=https://www.uschamber.com/sites/default/files/uscc_HistoryBook.pdf|website=U.S. Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref>
In 2005 there were 2,800 chambers of commerce in the United States and 102 chambers representing U.S. businesses overseas.<ref name="Weir2007_121">{{cite book|author=Robert E. Weir|title=Class in America: A-G|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y7n2tJVd3YsC&pg=PA121|accessdate=8 February 2012|year=2007|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-33720-8|pages=121–}}</ref> According to the Association for Chamber of Commerce Executives (ACCE), there are approximately 3,000 chambers of commerce with at least one staff person and "thousands more established as strictly volunteer entities".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acce.org/whatisachamber/ |title=What is a Chamber? |accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
===State chambers=== State chambers of commerce are much different from local and regional chambers of commerce, as they work on state and sometimes federal issues impacting the business community. Just as the local chamber is critical to the local business community, state chambers serve a unique function, serving as a third party voice on important business legislation that impact the business community and are critical in shaping legislation in their respective state. State Chambers work with their Governor, state representatives, state senators, US congressional leaders and US Senators. In comparison with state trade associations, which serve as a voice and resource to a particular industry, state chambers are looked to as a respected voice, representing the entire business community to enhance and advocate for a better business environment.
===National and international chambers=== Understanding the National or International need for understanding and information is the key service that these level of chambers of commerce provide. These services are in most cases are at no fee or cost to their members, some of the resources offer personal and/or business services that may have a very low fee (Memberships to other association like the NRA etc.).
===Compulsory or public-law chambers=== Under the compulsory or public law model, [[Business|enterprises]] of certain sizes, types, or sectors are obliged to become members of the chamber. This model is common in [[European Union]] countries (e.g. France,<ref>[[André-Pierre Nouvion]], ''Chambres de commerce et d'industrie'' - Encyclopédie juridique [[Dalloz]] - Répertoire de droit commercial, 2005</ref> Germany, [[Italy]], Spain, Austria), as well as Japan. Main tasks of the chambers are foreign trade promotion, vocational training, regional economic development, and general services to their members. The chambers were given responsibilities of public administration in various fields by the state which they exercise in order management. The chambers also have a consultative function; this means the chambers must be consulted whenever a new law related to industry or commerce is proposed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cipe.org/programs/training/pdf/Chamber_Primer.pdf |title=Markus Pilgrim and Ralf Meier, Chamber Primer |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=21 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107031727/http://www.cipe.org/programs/training/pdf/Chamber_Primer.pdf |archivedate=7 January 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
In Germany, the chambers of commerce and industry (''IHK - Industrie- und Handelskammer'') and the chambers of skilled crafts (''HwK - Handwerkskammer'') are public statutory bodies with self-administration under the inspectorate of the state ministry of economy. Enterprises are members by law according to the chamber act (''IHK-Gesetz'') of 1956. Because of this, such chambers are much bigger than chambers under private law. IHK Munich, the biggest German chamber of commerce, has 350,000 member companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=IHK München|url=http://www.muenchen.ihk.de|accessdate=31 August 2010}}</ref> Germany also has compulsory chambers for "free occupations" such as architects, dentists, engineers, lawyers, notaries, physicians and pharmacists.
===Continental/private law chambers=== Under the private model, which exists in English-speaking countries like USA, [[Canada]] or the UK, but as well in [[Sweden]], [[Finland]],{{cn|date=September 2016}} [[Norway]] and [[Denmark]], companies are not obligated to become chamber members. However, companies often become members to develop their business contacts and, regarding the local chambers (the most common level of organization), to demonstrate a commitment to the local economy. Though governments are not required to consult chambers on proposed laws, the chambers are often contacted given their local influence and membership numbers.
===Multilateral chambers=== A multilateral chamber is formed of companies (and sometimes individuals) from different countries with a common business interest towards or in a specific country. It can further be active in representing the interests of local and foreign investors in that specific country, achieved through promotion and proactivity regarding the general business environment. Multilateral chambers of commerce are independent entities strengthening business relations and interactions between all economic players, and their members may benefit from a broad range of activities that enhance the visibility and reputation of their business.
==Surveys== In many countries Chambers of Commerce are a source of private sector information. The information is usually gathered by surveying Chamber members. The [[British Chambers of Commerce]] Quarterly Economic Survey is an example of a Chambers of Commerce survey that is used by official governmental departments as a guide to the performance of the economy.<ref>[http://www.economicsurvey.org.uk British Chambers of Commerce Quarterly Economic Survey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607224146/http://www.economicsurvey.org.uk/ |date=7 June 2014 }}. BCC. 2014. Retrieved on 16 June 2014.</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Lobbying]] *[[Non-governmental organization]] *[[Trade group]] *[[Trade union]] *[[British Chambers of Commerce]] *[[United States Chamber of Commerce]] *[[Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce & Industry]] *[[Camera di Commercio, Industria, Agricoltura e Artigianato]] - Italy *{{Lookfrom}} *{{in title}} *{{Lookfrom|Chamber of Commerce and Industry}} *{{in title|Chamber of Commerce and Industry}} *[[European Federation of Bilateral Chambers of Commerce]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Chambers of commerce}} <!-- As every chamber of commerce in the world cannot be listed, please limit this list to reliable resources on all chambers --> *[http://www.iccwbo.org/wcf/co/id9416/index.html International Chamber of Commerce / World Chambers Federation] *[http://www.ChamberSearch.com Chamber Search] {{Business organizations}} {{Authority control}}

{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=July 2016}} {{refimprove|date=July 2010}} }}
{{Infobox magazine | title = eWeek | image_file = EWeekCover.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = John Pallatto (since 2012) | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | frequency = Semimonthly | circulation = 225,000 | category = [[Computer magazine]], Business magazine | company = [[QuinStreet]] | founded = 1983 | country = United States | language = English | website = {{URL|eweek.com}} | issn = 1530-6283 }} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''eWeek''|noerror}} <!-- overrides Infobox magazine, which uppercase the initial --> '''''eWeek''''' (''Enterprise Newsweekly'', stylized as ''eWEEK'') is a technology and business [[magazine]], owned by [[QuinStreet]]. The magazine was acquired in 2012 by QuinStreet from the company Ziff-Davis, owner of the publication for all of its life up to that point, along with Baseline.com, ChannelInsider.com, CIOInsight.com, and WebBuyersGuide.com.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/btob/quinstreet-acquires-ziff-davis-enterprise/285537/|title=QuinStreet acquires Ziff Davis Enterprise|last=Callahan|first=Sean|date=February 6, 2012|work=Ad Week|accessdate=June 2, 2014}}</ref>
''eWeek'' was started under the name ''PCWeek'' on February 28, 1984.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.eweek.com/it-management/eweek-at-25-a-look-at-the-publication-s-audacious-beginnings-and-exciting-future|title=eWEEK at 25: A Look at the Publication's Audacious Beginnings and Exciting Future|work=eWEEK|access-date=2017-05-18|language=en-US}}</ref> The magazine was called ''PCWeek'' all the way up until the year 2000, during which time it covered the rise of business computing in America; as ''eWeek'', it has increased its online presence and covers more kinds of worldwide technologies.
== History == ''PCWeek'' was formed under the notion that computers could be used as business tools. The world of personal computing was changing as processing power grew exponentially. This new computational ability made computers a new and very effective business tool, and soon enough all sorts of companies were buying IBM PCs. ''PCWeek'' took advantage of this rising popularity by becoming the one stop source for all things business-computing oriented.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.eweek.com/pc-hardware/30-years-ago-pc-week-chronicles-explosive-growth-of-ibm-compatible-pcs|title=30 Years Ago: PC Week Chronicles Explosive Growth of IBM-Compatible PCs|work=eWEEK|access-date=2017-05-18|language=en-US}}</ref> Important members of the team that started ''PCWeek'' were John Dodge, the first news editor, Lois Paul, the first features editor, and Sam Whitmore, the first reporter who later went on to become editor-in-chief.
Although ''PCWeek''<nowiki/>'s official first publication was February 28, 1984, a "sample version" of the magazine was available at a [[COMDEX]] convention in 1983. At the time, the concept of ''PCWeek'' was a "radical idea".<ref name=":0" /> Few saw any real need for a "weekly news magazine about personal computers" that was business-oriented. In addition, many magazines at the time already covered business computing, such as [[Datamation]] and [[Computerworld]]. There were also magazines dedicated to hobbyist machines, so it seemed there was no place for a weekly issue to fit in.<ref name=":1" /> Once the first few publications came out, it seemed like these initial suspicions had been correct. The first month of weekly issues had only 22 pages of advertising on average, well below industry standard.<ref name=":2">citation pending</ref>
After a rocky first few months, things began to turn around. ''PCWeek'' began establishing itself as the best source for information on business computing. The magazine started breaking big stories before anyone else would. Such as news on a "new version of the Compaq", the "IBM PC AT", and the new "Intel 80286 processor".<ref name=":0" /> The magazine also provided extensive reviews for PCs capable of helping to run businesses. John Pallatto, a writer for ''PCWeek'' in its first year, produced a full "buyer's guide" on all DOS-compatible PCs on the market.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.eweek.com/pc-hardware/pc-week-eweek-chronicler-of-the-pc-revolution-for-25-years|title=PC WEEK/eWEEK: Chronicler of the PC Revolution for 25 years|work=eWEEK|access-date=2017-05-18|language=en-US}}</ref> By the end of the first year, ''PCWeek''<nowiki/>'s numbers had skyrocketed. The average number of advertising pages for the last month was 74.875.<ref name=":2" /> The publication owed its resounding success to the increasing popularity of IBM PCs,<ref name=":1" /> but also to their style of reporting. Sam Whitmore describes it as "gritty, kick the door down, break your secret plans" and says that they had "so much fun spoiling people's days". David Strom, the executive editor in charge of "reviews, opinion, and analysis" at the time identified their "direct contact with industry leaders" as part of why they were able to break such killer stories.<ref name=":0" />
''PCWeek's'' audience was also important to their success. Early promotional publications from ''PCWeek'' show them describing their key audience as "volume buyers", that is, people and companies that would buy PCs in bulk for business purposes.<ref name=":2" /> With this the magazine was able to show big computer companies that advertising in an issue of ''PCWeek'' was the best possible way to get their product seen by the biggest and most important buyers.
Following the turn-around success in its first couple of years, ''PCWeek'' only got better. Important people involved in between ''PCWeek's'' initial success and change to ''eWeek'' were David Strom, Sam Whitmore, Mike Edelhart, [[Gina Smith (author)|Gina Smith]], Peter Coffee, Paul Bonner, and many others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://strom.wordpress.com/2013/08/06/pcweek-2/|title=In tribute to PC Week’s original staffers|last=Strom|first=David|date=2013-08-06|website=David Strom's Web Informant|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref> The team behind the magazine was getting better and better. Jim Louderback, a lab director at ''PCWeek'' as of 1991, describes how they were able to "get a product in on Wednesday, [review it], and have it on the front page on Monday" and that "that was something we were the first to do".<ref name=":0" /> The publication was "perfectly positioned" to be the source for all information on what PCs were worth looking at for business purposes.<ref name=":1" /> They broke stories spoiling products from [[IBM]], [[Lotus Development|Lotus]], and others as a result of incredible work by reporters like [[Gina Smith (author)|Gina Smith]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://strom.wordpress.com/2009/11/01/pc-week/|title=25 Years of PC Week|last=Strom|first=David|date=2009-11-01|website=David Strom's Web Informant|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref>
Leading up to its name-change, ''PCWeek'' began building an online presence. They were one of the first magazines to do so, and they had reviews about and coverage of the emergence of the [[World Wide Web]] that were "ahead of the game".<ref name=":0" /> The switch to the name ''eWeek'' and an even greater online presence was overseen by Eric Lundquist, editor-in-chief at the time.
Finally, in 2012, ''eWeek'' and other Ziff Davis assets were acquired by the company [[QuinStreet]], which now runs many tech-oriented publications.<ref name=":3" />
== Evolution == ''PCWeek'' evolved as the whole PC Industry evolved. The early success of the IBM PC and the [[VisiCalc|Visicalc]] and [[Lotus 1-2-3]] spreadsheet programs gave ''PCWeek'' the coverage they needed to get on their feet.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5" /> The magazine also developed a very active audience of people telling the team at ''PCWeek'' "about their experiences, good and bad, as they worked with the products".<ref name=":4" /> So ''PCWeek'' was also able to evolve with feedback from their active readers.
In the 21st century, business PCs have gone from "supporting" businesses to "driving" them, and there's been an increasing need for "unbiased, expert testing of the technology". ''eWeek'' has become much more oriented towards "Lab-based product evaluation" as a result of this.<ref name=":0" /> In terms of news, ''eWeek'' now covers all different sorts of tech, and they focus mainly on things like cloud computing, mobile technology, data center and infrastructure, security and enterprise applications, as well as IT careers and leadership information.<ref name="prn">{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/eweek-magazine-increases-investment-in-editorial--circulation-reveals-new-look-70806277.html|title=eWEEK Magazine Increases Investment in Editorial & Circulation; Reveals New Look|date=April 7, 2003|work=PR Newswire|accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
''eWeek'' has stated their mission as hoping to provide technology decision-makers with a mix of breaking news, analysis, trends, and reviews to help them make educated IT buying decisions.<ref name="prn" />
== Influence == ''PCWeek'' had a key influence on the PC Industry that it covered. The magazines success contributed to the success of business PCs just as the success of business PCs contributed to the success of ''PCWeek''. Following the magazine's success, "Anybody who had anything to do with buying PC products in a corporate environment" sought after access to a ''PCWeek'' subscription.<ref name=":4" /> John Pallatto characterizes the rise of PCs in 1985 as a "social phenomenon", and says that "the most sought-after status symbol on Wall Street in 1985... was the key to unlock the power switch on an IBM PC AT".<ref name=":4" /> It is also said that "in those early days", ''PCWeek'' could help make a small startup "PC maker" or "software developer" successful with only "a few column inches of editorial".<ref name=":1" />
The stories ''PCWeek'' covered were also important, and ended up having noticeable effects on the industry. Each issue would break stories that would completely spoil the secret plans of some big tech company, resulting in faster adoption of new technologies as information was spread about them before they were even out. One story from ''PCWeek'' that is well known is their coverage of "the famous 1994 flaw in the numerical processor in Intel's Pentium chip". The news they broke on Intel's processor, along with other research, cause Intel to actually pull back and fix their chips before offering new ones.<ref name=":0" /> Another famous part of ''PCWeek'' was the fictional gossip columnist by the name of "Spencer F. Katt". The column would cover all sorts of rumors and gossip about the PC Industry, and the character of Spencer F. Katt became a famous icon of the entire world of computing.<ref name=":0" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.eweek.com/}}

{{Infobox person | name = Edwin Soeryadjaya | caption = Edwin Soeryadajaya, February 2012 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|7|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Jakarta]], Indonesia | nationality = [[Indonesia]]n | residence = [[Jakarta]], Indonesia | education = Bachelor of Arts/Science | alma_mater =[[University of Southern California|University of Southern California, United States]] | occupation = Founder of [[Saratoga Investama Sedaya]]
Co-Founder of [[Adaro Energy]] | networth = {{gain}} US$ 1,4 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (March 2012) | parents = [[William Soeryadjaya]] (father)
Lily Anwar (mother) | known_for = Indonesia's 12th wealthiest people (2012), 913th world (March 2012) }} '''Edwin Soeryadjaya''' (born 17 July 1949) also known as '''Tjia Han Pun''' is a [[Chinese Indonesian]] businessman, He is the son of the late [[William Soeryadjaya]], who founded automotive group [[Astra International]]. Soeryadjaya set up investment firm [[Saratoga Investama Sedaya]] in 1998. Today, through his private equity firm, PT Saratoga Investama Sedaya, he holds an ownership in coal miner [[Adaro Energy]]. He also has a stake in cell tower company Tower Bersama Infrastructure and bought [[Mandala Airlines]] in 2011 with his partner [[Sandiaga Salahudin Uno|Sandiaga Uno]].{{cite news|title=Biography of Edwin Soeryadjaya|url=http://www.tokohindonesia.com/biografi/article/285-ensiklopedi/3776-taipan-tangguh-yang-dihormati}} Currently Edwin was known as the 12th richest people of Indonesia and the #913 in the world according to [[Forbes]].https://www.forbes.com/profile/edwin-soeryadjaya/ ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soeryadjaya, Edwin}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Jakarta]] [[Category:Indonesian billionaires]] [[Category:Indonesian businesspeople]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Indonesian Christians]] [[Category:Soeryadjaya family]]

'''Enrollment Management''' is a term that is used frequently in higher education to describe well-planned strategies and tactics to shape the enrollment of an institution and meet established goals. Plainly stated, enrollment management is an organizational concept and a systematic set of activities designed to enable educational institutions to exert more influence over their student enrollments. {{ref|hossler}}
Such practices often include marketing, admission policies, retention programs, and financial aid awarding. Strategies and tactics are informed by collection, analysis, and use of data to project successful outcomes. Activities that produce measurable improvements in yields are continued and/or expanded, while those activities that do not are discontinued or restructured. Competitive efforts to recruit students is a common emphasis of enrollment managers.
The numbers of universities and colleges instituting offices of "enrollment management" have increased in recent years. These offices serve to provide direction and coordination of efforts of multiple offices such as admissions, financial aid, registration, and other student services. Often these offices are part of an enrollment management division.
Some of the typical aims of enrollment management include:
* Improving yields at inquiry, application, and enrollment stages. {{ref|citation1}} * Increasing net revenue, usually by improving the proportion of entering students capable of paying most or all of unsubsidized tuition ("full-pays") {{ref|quirk}} * Increasing demographic diversity {{ref|citation2}} * Improving retention rates * Increasing applicant pools
According to Matthew Quirk {{ref|quirk3}}: :More-advanced enrollment managers also tend to focus as much on retaining admitted students as on deciding whom to recruit and accept. They smooth out administrative hassles, guarantee at-risk students the advising and academic help they need, and ensure that the different parts of the university's bureaucracy work together to get students out the door with a degree.
== See also == *[[Strategic Enrollment Management]] *[[Graduate enrollment management]] [http://www.simpleapply.com/blog Enrollment Management Blog] [https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/end-paper-forms-finally-fred-ritman/]
==Notes== # {{note|citation2}} Answers.com [http://www.answers.com/topic/enrollment-management-in-higher-education "Enrollment Management in Higher Education"] # {{note|quirk}} ibid # {{note|quirk}} Matthew Quirk, 2005 [https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/print/200511/financial-aid-leveraging The Best Class Money Can Buy], The Atlantic Monthly, Nov. 2005 # {{note|citation1}} CSCSR [http://www.cscsr.org/article_enrollment_management.htm "Parkland College Enrollment Management Model"] # {{note|quirk2}} Matthew Quirk, op. cit.
[[Category:Educational administration]]

revision.comment: See [[Special:Permanentlink/788151804#Mass cat-a-lot reversion of User:Skr15081997 required]]; reverted edits were contrary to [[WP:SUBCAT]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Eric Leslie Gandar Dower''' (1894 – 4 October 1987) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[Unionist Party (Scotland)|Unionist Party]] politician and businessman.
He was educated at [[Brighton College]], like his elder brother Leonard, and at [[Jesus College, Cambridge]], and trained for the stage at the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]], touring with a number of theatre companies.
Gandar Dower established [[Aberdeen Airport]] and pioneered Scottish Air Lines between [[Aberdeen]] and [[Edinburgh]], [[Glasgow]], [[Wick, Highland|Wick]], [[Thurso]], [[Kirkwall]], and [[Stromness]], as well as the first [[United Kingdom|British]]/[[Norway|Norwegian]] Air Line between [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] and [[Stavanger]] in 1937. He served as a Flight Lieutenant in the [[Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve]] from 1940 to 1943.
Following the War, he was elected as Conservative [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Caithness and Sutherland (UK Parliament constituency)|Caithness and Sutherland]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|1945 general election]] with a majority of just 6 in the tightest ever three-way marginal: just 61 votes separated him from the third-placed candidate, [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] parliamentary leader [[Archibald Sinclair]]. Sinclair had acted as [[Secretary of State for Air]] during [[World War II]] and could not spend much time in his constituency, Britain's northernmost mainland seat.
Gandar Dower had based his 1945 election platform on serving as a wartime MP until the end of the conflict with [[Japan]]. His election address stated, "If I am returned I shall resign when Japan is beaten and stand again at the by-election which will follow, so that you can decide whether you wish me to continue as your representative in peace" and followed this up with an eve-of-poll "special message" stating, "Note - Gandar Dower, if elected, has pledged himself to resign at the end of the Japanese war and to stand again at the resultant by-election."''
In his victory speech at the declaration, he said, "Don't regard me as a Unionist. I am a member of the National Party until the end of the Japanese war, when you will then have a chance again to put me in or out."<ref>The Times, Tuesday, 19 Nov 1946; pg. 5; Issue 50612; col D </ref>
After the war ended on 14 August 1945, Gandar Dower did not resign, but pledged to do so "later".<ref>The Times, Monday, 25 Feb 1946; pg. 2; Issue 50385; col C</ref>
On 14 February 1946, Gandar Dower announced that he would shortly be resigning his seat but later withdrew the resignation.<ref>The Times, Friday, 15 Feb 1946; pg. 2; Issue 50377; col C</ref>
On 28 December 1946, Gandar Dower offered to resign in the New Year, citing the marriage of his Private Secretary as a reason, but he withdrew this resignation on 11 February, citing the "rumours and cross-rumours" in the press which had been caused by his announcement, and how they "have been damaging to the Unionist cause."<ref>The Times, Saturday, 28 Dec 1946; pg. 4; Issue 50644; col F ; The Times, Wednesday, 12 Feb 1947; pg. 4; Issue 50683; col E ; The Times, Monday, 17 Feb 1947; pg. 5; Issue 50687; col F</ref> On 30 June 1947, ''The Times'' reported, "With the forthcoming fusion of the [[Caithness]] and [[Sutherland]] Conservative Associations it is certain that there will be no by-election in this constituency. Backed by the unanimous support of both associations, Mr. E.L. Gandar Dower, the Conservative MP for Caithness and Sutherland, will hold his seat probably until the next General Election."<ref>The Times, Monday, 30 Jun 1947; pg. 4; Issue 50800; col D</ref>
At a 15 September 1948 meeting of his local Conservative Association, he attempted to bring matters to a head by calling on the association to renominate him as the Conservative candidate for a by-election that he now intended to trigger. He was overwhelmingly defeated, with only 8 members voting for him to follow through with this course of action and numerous members expressing their dissatisfaction.<ref>The Times, Thursday, 16 Sep 1948; pg. 3; Issue 51178; col C</ref> In response to this, he declared that he would be standing at the next general election as an Independent, and from 3 October 1948, he withdrew from the Conservative whip.<ref>The Times, Monday, 4 Oct 1948; pg. 5; Issue 51193; col A</ref> On 12 December 1948, the Caithness and Sutherland Conservatives selected [[David Robertson (UK politician)|David Robertson]] to replace Gandar Dower. In the event, Gandar Dower decided not to seek re-election at all, and he retired at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1950|1950 general election]].
Gandar Dower's brother, [[Alan Gandar Dower|Alan]], also served as a Conservative member of parliament, while another, [[Kenneth Gandar-Dower|Kenneth]], was a leading explorer and navigator.<ref>Malies, J. (2004) "Dower, Kenneth Cecil Gandar- (1908–1944)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press</ref> All used different versions of their surname: Gandar Dower, Dower and Gandar-Dower respectively.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{Hansard-contribs | mr-eric-gandar-dower | Eric Gandar Dower }} *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/history/scotlandonfilm/media_clips/clip_display.shtml?topic=transport&subtopic=air&clip_name=nationalisation_aa&media_type=audio Audio clip of BBC interview with Gandar Dower]
{{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Caithness and Sutherland (UK Parliament constituency)|Caithness and Sutherland]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|1945]]–[[United Kingdom general election, 1950|1950]] | before = [[Archibald Sinclair, 1st Viscount Thurso|Archibald Sinclair]] | after = [[David Robertson (UK politician)|David Robertson]] }} {{s-end}}

{{Infobox person | name = Evelyn Lauder | birth_name = Evelyn Hausner | birth_date = August 12, 1936 | birth_place = [[Vienna, Austria]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|2011|11|12|1936|8|12}} | death_place = [[New York, New York]] | nationality = Austrian American | spouse = {{marriage|[[Leonard Lauder]]|1959|2011|reason=d}} | children = [[William P. Lauder]]
Gary Lauder | website = [http://www.evelynlauder.com EvelynLauder.com] }} '''Evelyn Lauder''' (née '''Hausner'''; August 12, 1936 – November 12, 2011){{cite news|last=Horyn|first=Cathy|title=Evelyn H. Lauder, Champion of Breast Cancer Research, Dies at 75|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/13/nyregion/evelyn-h-lauder-champion-of-breast-cancer-research-dies-at-75.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 12, 2011}} was an [[United States|Austrian American]] businesswoman, socialite and philanthropist who has been credited as one of the creators and popularizers of the [[pink ribbon]] as a symbol for awareness of [[breast cancer]].{{cite news|title=Evelyn Lauder, who created breast cancer's pink ribbon, dies at 75|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/13/us/evelyn-lauder-obit/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|work=[[CNN]]|date=2011-11-13|accessdate=2011-11-13}} ==Early life== She was born Evelyn Hausner in 1936 in [[Vienna, Austria]], to a [[Austrian Jews|Jewish]] family.[http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/news/national_world/article_0a89de20-1075-11e1-b524-001cc4c03286.Cleveland Jewish News: "Passing of Evelyn Lauder marked by Jewish activists against breast cancer"] November 16, 2011 Lauder’s family fled [[Nazi]]-occupied Austria in 1938, using their household silver to get visas to [[Belgium]]. They then moved on to [[England]] where her mother was sent to an [[List of concentration and internment camps#Isle of Man|internment camp]] on the [[Isle of Man]] and Evelyn was placed in a nursery. The family arrived in [[New York City]] in 1940.{{cite web |url=http://www.wlwt.com/health/29757407/detail.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120525235227/http://www.wlwt.com/health/29757407/detail.html |archivedate=2012-05-25 |df= }}[http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=245606 Jerusalem Post: "Breast cancer ‘pink ribbon’ pioneer dies" By JORDANA HORN] November 15, 2011 Lauder would later recall that she was asleep when the ship bringing them to the United States arrived in [[New York Harbor]] and her mother woke her up to see the [[Statue of Liberty]].[http://www.wwd.com/beauty-industry-news/people/evelyn-lauder-dies-at-age-75-5365922?full=true Women's Wear Daily: "Remembering Evelyn Lauder" By Julie Naughton and Pete Born] November 15, 2011 During the war years her father worked as a diamond cutter; then the family opened the first of what became a chain of five dress shops in Manhattan.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/medicine-obituaries/8977365/Evelyn-Lauder.html The Telegraph: "Obituary: Evelyn Lauder"] December 25, 2011 She graduated from Hunter College High School in 1954.{{Cite web|url = http://www.hunterschools.org/notable-alumni|title = Hunter College Campus Schools ~Notable Alumnae/i|date = |accessdate = 19 September 2014|website = Hunter College Campus Schools|publisher = |last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140919162248/http://www.hunterschools.org/notable-alumni|archivedate = 19 September 2014}} She then attended [[Hunter College]], part of the [[City University of New York]], where she studied Psychology and Anthropology and also where she met her future husband, [[Leonard Lauder]], then a trainee naval officer, on a blind date. She graduated from Hunter College in 1958.Staff. [https://www.nytimes.com/1959/07/06/archives/miss-hausner-wed-to-leonard-lauder.html "Miss Hausner Wed To Leonard Lauder"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 6, 1959. Accessed January 11, 2008. The couple were married on July 5, 1959. After the marriage, she worked for several years as a public school teacher in [[Harlem]] before leaving to work with her husband at the company founded in 1946 by her mother-in-law, [[Estée Lauder (person)|Estée Lauder]], which at the time sold six products: a red lipstick, creams, lotions, and Youth Dew fragrance in a bath oil. ==Career== Lauder was the Senior Corporate Vice President of the [[Estée Lauder Companies]] and a member of the board of overseers at the [[Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center]]. A 1995 profile in ''[[The New York Times]]'' called her "an immaculately turned-out, awesomely organized woman" who had started to fill the public role that had been filled by her mother-in-law, Estée Lauder.Nemy, Enid. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=990CE7DD153DF931A35751C0A963958260 "AT WORK WITH: Evelyn Lauder; From Pink Lipstick To Pink Ribbons"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 2, 1995. Accessed January 11, 2008. Lauder, an executive at Estée Lauder, created the [[Clinique]] [[brand name]] and developed its [[product line]].{{cite news|first=Michelle|last=Dargan|title=Service to be Monday for Evelyn Lauder, beauty exec and pink ribbon co-creator|url=http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/news/service-to-be-monday-for-evelyn-lauder-beauty-1966283.html|work=[[Palm Beach Daily News]]|date=2011-11-13|accessdate=2011-11-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513210413/http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/news/service-to-be-monday-for-evelyn-lauder-beauty-1966283.html|archivedate=2012-05-13|df=}} She worked as the training director for Clinique and was the first person to wear the trademark white [[lab coat]], now worn by Clinique salespeople at cosmetic departments worldwide. ==Breast cancer activist== Lauder personally raised much of the $13.6 million that went to create the '''Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center''' at [[Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center]], which opened in October 1992 and focuses on the treatment and diagnosis of breast cancer. She helped raise an additional $5 million to create an endowment to be used to fund [[clinical research]] there. ''Self'' magazine's first annual issue for [[National Breast Cancer Awareness Month]] came after an April 1991 lunch at the [[21 Club]], at which Lauder discussed ideas for articles about breast cancer with her friend [[Alexandra Penney]], who was then serving as editor of ''[[Self (magazine)|Self]]''.Brozan, Nadine. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9D0CE7D8133FF932A1575AC0A967958260 "Chronicle"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 21, 1991. Accessed January 11, 2009. Together with Penney, Lauder established [[The Breast Cancer Research Foundation]] and formalized the [[pink ribbon]] as a symbol for [[breast cancer awareness]] as part of ''Self'' magazine's second annual Breast Cancer Awareness Month issue in 1992. Penney's inspiration to improve on the success of the magazine's first annual issue was to create a ribbon that would be placed in Estee Lauder's New York City stores. Lauder made the commitment to have the ribbons placed on the company's cosmetics counters across the United States.Romans, Christine. [http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/01/09/madoff.alexandra.penney/index.html "Life savings gone, 'Madoffed' best-selling writer back at work"], ''[[CNN]]'', January 9, 2009. Accessed January 11, 2009.Fernandez, Sandy M. [http://thinkbeforeyoupink.org/Pages/PrettyInPink.html "Pretty in Pink"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218231238/http://thinkbeforeyoupink.org/Pages/PrettyInPink.html |date=2007-12-18 }}, [[Breast Cancer Action]] reprinted from MAMM, June/July 1998. Accessed January 11, 2009. By 1993, Lauder had overseen the creation of a new shade called Pink Ribbon that was part of her personal and corporate effort to raise breast cancer awareness. Her husband paid for the cost of registering The Breast Cancer Research Foundation in all 50 states. By the start of 1995, some $900,000 had been raised for the foundation, including $120,000 from the sale of Pink Ribbon lipstick and blusher and $190,000 from the sale of the [[Clinique]] Berry Kiss pink lipstick. By October 2008, the Estée Lauder Companies estimated that the firm's Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign had raised $335 million towards research and distributed 80 million pink ribbons.[http://www.esteelauder.com/about/breast_cancer_awareness.tmpl Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207204700/http://www.esteelauder.com/about/breast_cancer_awareness.tmpl |date=2009-02-07 }}, [[Estée Lauder Companies]]. Accessed January 11, 2009. Following Lauder's death, [[Delta Air Lines]], which had already dedicated one of its [[Boeing 767|Boeing 767-400ER]] long-haul planes in honor of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation that Lauder founded and painted it in a pink livery while Lauder was living, re-christened and renamed the same plane in her memory.[http://news.delta.com/index.php?s=20295&item=124040 Delta Dedicates 'Pink Plane' to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation® Founder Evelyn Lauder], accessed December 8, 2014 ==Personal life== She was married to [[Leonard Lauder]], former Chairman of the Estée Lauder Companies, from 1959 until her death. They had two sons: *[[William P. Lauder]], Executive Chairman of the Estée Lauder Companies; and[http://www.elcompanies.com/Pages/PressReleaseStory.aspx?ReleaseId=1734 Estee Lauder Company website press release: " The Estée Lauder Companies Mourns the Death of Evelyn H. Lauder"] November 11, 2011 *[[Gary M. Lauder]], Managing Director of Lauder Partners LLC. He graduated from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and received an M.B.A. degree from [[Stanford University]]. In 1994, Gary married Laura Heller, daughter of Marlyn G. McClaskey and William A. Heller of California. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the [[Central Synagogue]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/25/style/weddings-laura-b-heller-and-gary-m-lauder.html New York Times: "WEDDINGS; Laura B. Heller and Gary M. Lauder"] September 25, 1994 Laura serves as General Partner of Lauder Partners. They have two children: Josh and Ellie.[http://www.bizjournals.com/prnewswire/press_releases/2012/02/28/SF60441 Biz Journals: "Venture Philanthropist Laura Lauder Honored in the Silicon Valley - The Lauder Family Celebrates the 2012 Rambam's Ladder Award for Righteous Giving"] February 28, 2012 ==Death== Evelyn Lauder died at home in [[Manhattan]] from complications of [[nongenetic ovarian cancer]].Salazar, Cristian (November 12, 2011). [https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jNwOeMsH3ljrDOC7SMOv0TDLBeWA Lauder, maker of breast cancer's pink ribbon, dies], ''[[Associated Press]]'' She was a longtime resident of [[Palm Beach, Florida]]. A private funeral service was held at the [[Central Synagogue]] in New York City. ==Awards And Nominations== '''Double Helix Medal''' * 2010: [http://doublehelixmedals.cshl.edu/history_10.html CSHL Double Helix Medal Honoree] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://evelynlauder.com/ Personal website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090328033646/http://www.elcompanies.com/the_company/executive_profiles/evelyn_h_lauder.asp Evelyn H. Lauder], [[Estée Lauder Companies]] * {{Find a Grave|80322553}} *[https://www.esteelauder.com.au/ Estée Lauder Official Website] *[https://www.clinique.com.au/ Clinique Official Website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lauder, Evelyn}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:American cosmetics businesspeople]] [[Category:American health activists]] [[Category:American people of Austrian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American retail chief executives]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:American women chief executives]] [[Category:Austrian chief executives]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Austrian health activists]] [[Category:Austrian Jews]] [[Category:Austrian philanthropists]] [[Category:Austrian socialites]] [[Category:Austrian women in business]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Florida]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Vienna]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New York (state)]] [[Category:Children of Holocaust survivors]] [[Category:Deaths from ovarian cancer]] [[Category:Hunter College alumni]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Lauder family]] [[Category:Northwestern University alumni]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:People from Palm Beach, Florida]] [[Category:Estée Lauder Companies]] [[Category:Activists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]]

[[File:Ferdinand Egeberg (1885).jpg|thumb|Ferdinand Julian Egeberg c. 1885]]
[[File:4xEgeberg-in1890.PNG |thumb|right|Egeberg (back right) with family members ]]
'''Ferdinand Julian Egeberg''' (23 November 1842 – 12 September 1921) was a Norwegian military officer, chamberlain and timber merchant. He is remembered for having founded the sports prize [[Egebergs Ærespris]], which was regarded as the highest achievement in Norwegian sport.
==Personal life== Egeberg was born in [[Moss, Norway|Moss]] in [[Østfold]], Norway. He was the son of merchant Peder Cappelen Egeberg and Hanna Wilhelmine Scheel.<ref name=stoo>{{cite book|title=Den kongelige norske Sankt Olavs Orden 1847-1947|first=O. Delphin|last=Amundsen|authorlink=Otto Delphin Amundsen|page=251|year=1947|publisher=Grøndahl|location=Oslo|language=Norwegian}}</ref> He was a brother of [[Einar Westye Egeberg, Sr.]] and a grandson of [[Westye Egeberg]].<ref name=snl-egeberg>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Egeberg|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/Egeberg|editor=Henriksen, Petter|language=Norwegian|accessdate=22 February 2010}}</ref>
He married Lucy Parr in 1876.<ref name=stoo2>{{cite book|title=Den kongelige norske Sankt Olavs Orden 1847-1947|first=O. Delphin|last=Amundsen|page=251|year=1947|publisher=Grøndahl|location=Oslo|language=Norwegian}}</ref> Their son [[Westye Parr Egeberg]] was a notable landowner. Through their daughter Esther Lucy Egeberg he was grandfather of painter and writer [[Ferdinand Finne]].<ref name=snl-egeberg>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Egeberg|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/Egeberg|editor=Henriksen, Petter|language=Norwegian|accessdate=22 February 2010}}</ref> He died in [[Tolga, Norway|Tolga]] in 1921, aged 78.<ref name=stoo/>
==Career== Egeberg was a naval officer from 1863, and served in the British [[Royal Navy]] from 1865. He was [[first lieutenant]] [[à la suite]] from 1874, and discharged in 1875.<ref name=stoo/> Together with his brother Einar, he took over his family's [[Oslo|Christiania]]-based timber company [[Westye Egeberg & Co]] in 1874, after the death of their father.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Egeberg, Einar Westye|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|publisher=Aschehoug|location=Oslo|editor=Bull, Edvard |editor-link=Edvard Bull, Sr. |editor2=[[Einar Jansen|Jansen, Einar]]|edition=1st|first=S. C.|last=Hammer|authorlink=Simon Christian Hammer|year=1926|volume=3|pages=424–425|language=Norwegian}}</ref> He was an associate from 1879. He served as [[Chamberlain (office)|Cabinet Chamberlain]] ({{lang-sv|kabinettskammarherre}}) for [[Oscar II of Sweden]] from 1887 to 1905.<ref name=stoo/>
Egeberg was decorated as a Knight, First Class of the [[Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav]] in 1891. He was a Commander, First Class of the Danish [[Order of the Dannebrog]], Knight Grand Officer of the [[Order of the Crown of Italy]], Officer of the French [[Légion d'honneur]], Commander of the Spanish [[Order of Charles III]], Knight Grand Officer of the Spanish [[Order of Isabella the Catholic]] and the Swedish [[Order of the Polar Star]], and recipient of [[King Oscar II]]'s Anniversary Medal.<ref name=stoo/>
==Egebergs Ærespris== Upon his 75th birthday in 1917, Egeberg donated {{NOK|10,000|lk=yes}} to the sports association [[Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports|Norges Riksforbund for Idræt]]. The donation was basis for the sports prize ''[[Egebergs Ærespris|Kabinetskammerherre Egebergs ærespris for alsidig idrett]]''. According to the original statutes approved in 1920, the fund's interests should be used for a stauette given to a sportsperson who, during the last two years, had excelled in one sport and also showed eminent performances in another, completely different sport. Egeberg also funded a design competition for the trophy, won by sculptor [[Magnus Vigrestad]]. The statuette became regarded as the highest achievement in Norwegian sport at the time. The first prize was awarded for 1918.<ref name=ni-100>{{cite book|title=Norsk idrett gjennom hundre år|first=Gunnar|last=Nordahl|first2=Odd|last2=Tyrihjell|pages=167–68|year=1961|publisher=Aschehoug|location=Oslo|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
The statutes have changed slightly over the years. Today the prize is awarded by the [[Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports]], and given to Norwegian sports people who have excelled nationally in at least two sports, and excelled internationally in at least one of these.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Egebergs ærespris|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|first=Rolf|last=Bryhn|url=http://www.snl.no/Egebergs_%C3%A6respris|editor=Henriksen, Petter|language=Norwegian|accessdate=22 February 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.idrettsforbundet.no/tema/utmerkelser-og-priser/ Egebergs Ærespris website (Norges idrettsforbund og olympiske og paralympiske komité)] {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Egeberg, Ferdinand Julian}} [[Category:1842 births]] [[Category:1921 deaths]] [[Category:People from Moss, Norway]] [[Category:Royal Norwegian Navy personnel]] [[Category:Royal Navy officers]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:Officiers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Isabella the Catholic]] [[Category:Commanders by Number of the Order of Isabella the Catholic]] [[Category:Commanders First Class of the Order of the Polar Star]]

revision.comment: a useful comparison of three technologies
revision.text:
'''Flame treatment''' is the application of a gas flame to the surface of a material to improve [[adhesion]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Aerogen flame treatment improves surface adhesion |publisher=[[Materials Today]]}}</ref><ref name="FarrisPozzoli2010">{{cite journal|last1=Farris|first1=Stefano|last2=Pozzoli|first2=Simone|last3=Biagioni|first3=Paolo|last4=Duó|first4=Lamberto|last5=Mancinelli|first5=Stefano|last6=Piergiovanni|first6=Luciano|title=The fundamentals of flame treatment for the surface activation of polyolefin polymers – A review|journal=Polymer|volume=51|issue=16|year=2010|pages=3591–3605|issn=0032-3861|doi=10.1016/j.polymer.2010.05.036}}</ref>
[[Polyolefin]]s, especially [[polyethylene]] and [[polypropylene]] bond poorly, because they consist of long non-[[Chemical polarity|polar]] molecules. Without special treatment, adhesives, ink, and other coatings cannot be applied to these materials. By rapidly applying intense heat to a surface, molecular chains are broken and polar functional groups are added. Flame treatment also burns off dust, fibers, oils, and other surface contaminates.
Flame treatment is faster than corona treatment, but requires more complicated and expensive equipment.
==Process== [[File:Blow Torch (3257353199).jpg|thumb|Flame from fuel premixed with air]] Fuel gas is pre-mixed with air, and the resulting [[Flame#Color|flame]] is directed at the surface to be treated. The flame has a light blue inner cone, called primary, and a dull blue outer cone, called secondary. The hottest part of the flame is the primary, which may be up {{nowrap|to 1800 °C.}} The tip of the inner cone (primary) contains an assortment of highly reactive chemicals, including unburned oxygen, carbon dioxide, water vapor, and [[Radical (chemistry)|free radicals]] [[Allotropes of oxygen#Atomic oxygen|atomic oxygen (O<sub>1</sub>)]] and [[Hydroxyl radical|hydroxyl (OH)]].
To treat a surface quickly and evenly, many gas jets, similar to the one on the right, are lined up in a long row on a single burner. The material being treated is quickly passed directly in front of or under the inner cones. The surface is in contact with the flame for less than a second. The surface is treated quickly, without time for the material to melt.
The reactive [[chemical species]] in the gas flame break the long-chain molecules in the plastic material, and attach themselves to the break points, resulting in polar point charges on the surface. On a microscopic scale, the surface also becomes rougher.<ref>{{cite web |title=The principle of flame treatment |publisher=Arcotec GmbH |url=http://www.arcotec.com/en/Flamme.htm |accessdate=September 10, 2016}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Chemistry of pressure-sensitive adhesives]] * [[Plasma activation]] * [[Corona treatment]] * [[Polymeric surface]] * [[Stone flaming]] * [[Surface finishing]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.pillartech.com/Surface-Treatment/In-The-News/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/35/Flame-Plasma-or-Corona-Treatment-whats-right-for-you Comparing Flame, Plasma, and Corona Treatments] [[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Plastics industry]]
{{tech-stub}}
